GRANT AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
Borrower  Government of Nepal 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communications 
Subsector: Roads and highways 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth 
Subtheme: Fostering physical infrastructure development 
   
Environment  Category A 
Assessment  The summary environmental impact assessment was disclosed to 
the public via the Asian Development Bank (ADB) website and 
submitted to ADB’s Board of Directors on 4 April 2006. 
   
Project Description  The Project will finance the construction and upgrading of about 
10 feeder roads measuring a total of about 490 kilometers (km). It 
will (i) provide roads to three district headquarters which are not 
currently connected and upgrade existing connection roads to all-
weather condition in 17 districts (of the country’s 75 districts); 
(ii) enhance capacity building of the Department of Roads (DOR) 
in  carrying  out  road  feasibility  studies—in  terms  of  economic, 
social, and safeguard aspects; and (iii) enhance capacity building 
of local construction and consulting services industries in road 
construction and contract management.   
The Project is the first ADB sector modality intervention in the 
transport sector in Nepal. A programmatic approach has been 
adopted to identify, screen, and prioritize candidate roads. The 
approach provides flexibility in project implementation under the 
present conflict situation in Nepal. 
   
Rationale  Poor road connectivity is a major development constraint for the 
country. Inadequate feeder roads worsen the isolation of remote 
rural areas, mostly in northern hilly regions. Rehabilitating and 
expanding  feeder  roads  will  contribute  to  inclusive  social  and 
economic  development.  Improved  access  of  remote  people  to 
social facilities and employment opportunities in major towns will 
help  foster  a  broad-based  and  inclusive  social  and  economic 
development  process  to  achieve  a  steady  decline  in  poverty. 
ADB’s support for the inclusive development process will assist 
the  Government  in  (i)  promoting  greater  balance  in  the 
development of different regions of the country; (ii) improving the 
poor’s  access  to  basic  services,  opportunities  for  economic 
advancement, and participation in the development process; and 
(iii) addressing  the  needs  of  disadvantaged,  women,  ethnic 
groups, and lower castes. 
The Project is in line with the Government’s priority strategies 
which plan to complete road connection to all districts in the next 
10  years,  particularly  in  the  northern  part  of  the  country.  The 
candidate roads are included in the Government’s 10-Year Road

ii   
Sector Midterm Program (2006–2015).  
 
The Project recognizes the importance of preventing HIV/AIDS 
and human trafficking, in line with the Government’s 10th 5-year- 
plan (2002–2007). The Project will (i) carry out designed activities 
to  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  groups  at  risk  to  HIV/AIDS  and 
trafficking, and (ii) increase access to HIV prevention services. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project will (i) support economic growth, particularly in rural 
communities; and (ii) help reduce the poverty of isolated people, 
mainly in hilly areas. An expanded and rehabilitated feeder road 
system  in  remote  areas  is  expected  to  enhance  access  to 
markets,  employment  opportunities,  and  health  and  education 
service centers in major towns and district headquarters. It will 
also contribute to sustained and broad-based economic growth 
and inclusive social development. The Project will construct new 
feeder roads to three district headquarters and upgrade existing 
district  roads  to  all-weather  condition  in  17  districts,  affecting 
about  1.4  million  people.  The  capacity  of  DOR  and  local 
construction and consulting services industries will be enhanced.  
   
Project Investment Plan  The investment cost of the Project is estimated at the equivalent 
of  $80  million,  including  taxes,  duties,  and  interest  and  other 
charges  during  construction  on  the  loan  cofinanced  by  the 
Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) Fund for 
International Development (OPEC Fund).  
   
Financing Plan  It is proposed that ADB will provide a grant of the equivalent of 
$55.2 million from the Asian Development Fund IX (ADF IX) grant 
program. The grant will finance the project cost except the cost for 
land acquisition and resettlement, taxes, and duties. The OPEC 
Fund will provide a loan of $10 million to finance the civil works 
cost of the road connectivity component. The OPEC Fund loan 
will be administered by ADB. The Government will finance $14.8 
million for the project cost, inclusive of taxes and duties, and the 
cost of land acquisition and resettlement.  
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2013 
   
Estimated Project  31 December 2012 
Completion Date 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Physical Planning and Works (MPPW)  
   
Implementation  DOR  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency.  The  existing  project 
Arrangements  implementation  unit,  which  is  responsible  for  implementing 
ongoing ADB-financed road projects, will be retained under DOR 
for the Project.

iii
Procurement  Civil works contracts estimated at more than $2 million will be 
procured  through  international  competitive  bidding.  Civil  works 
contracts worth $2 million or less will be procured through national 
competitive  bidding  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.  MPPW 
standard  bidding  documents  for  procurement  of  civil  works 
developed under ADB technical assistance (TA) will be used for all 
national competitive bidding contracts.  
Bidders  will  be  post-qualified  by  applying  a  single-stage,  one-
envelope bidding procedure. Equipment will be procured using 
(i) international  competitive  bidding  for  contracts  estimated  at 
more than $1 million; (ii) limited international bidding for contracts 
estimated  at  $100,000–$1,000,000;  and  (iii)  direct  contracting 
arrangements for contracts valued at less than $100,000. 
   
Consulting Services  A consulting firm will be recruited using ADB's quality- and cost-
based selection procedure in accordance with Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  Its 
Borrowers. About 60 person-months of international consultants 
and 1,322 person-months of national consultants will be required 
for the Project. Consultants will carry out (i) detailed design and 
construction  supervision  of  sample  roads;  and  (ii)  feasibility 
studies,  preliminary,  and  detailed  design  and  construction 
supervision of non-sample roads. This will be done in line with 
government  and  ADB  policies  and  guidelines,  and  based  on 
demonstrated  sample  methodology  applied  to  sample  road 
feasibility and preliminary design. Consultants will also assist DOR 
in  developing  a  baseline  for  systematic  project  performance 
management systems monitoring and evaluation. Consultants will 
(i)  supervise  and  monitor  the  implementation  of  resettlement 
activities,  environment  management  plans,  the  road  safety 
program, and the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program; and (ii) 
prepare the overall project completion report.    
Local  nongovernment  organizations  will  be  recruited  for  about 
36 person-months to carry out the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking 
program.  
MPPW  will  recruit  2  person-months  of  international  individual 
consultants  and  4  person-months  of  domestic  individual 
consultants,  on  the  recommendation  of  the  National  Vigilance 
Centre, to carry out project technical auditing in line with ADB's 
procedures and approved terms of reference.  
   
Project Benefits and  The  districts  covered  by  the  Project  have  a  high  poverty 
Beneficiaries  incidence,  from  37.4%  to  42.9%,  compared  with  the  national 
average of 30.8%. Most of these districts are considered food 
insecure  districts.  The  social  survey  indicates  that  better  road 
connectivity  would  help  farmers  sell  agricultural  products  to 
neighboring  markets,  which  would  provide  more  agricultural 
employment,  particularly  benefiting  the  poor.  The  Project  will 
create employment opportunities for skilled and unskilled labor 
during implementation. Unskilled labor will be employed directly in 
road  construction  and  indirectly  in  providing  materials  and

iv   
services  for  contractors.  The  Project  will  provide  reliable  and 
shortened road access to social services, particularly health care 
services,  education  facilities,  and  drinking  water  supply.  The 
Project will improve access to hinterlands for business and private 
sector  investments,  especially  agro-industries  and  the  tourism 
industry. The poverty impact ratio of the sample roads is estimated 
at 0.44, indicating that substantial benefits may accrue to the poor. 
 
Risks and Assumptions  ADB’s  portfolio  performance  in  Nepal  improved  in  2005,  as 
reflected in increased contract awards and disbursement, in spite 
of very challenging circumstances caused by escalation of the 
security  conflict  since  2000.  The  Project  has  been  carefully 
formulated to manage and mitigate risks. Advance recruitment will 
help expedite consultant mobilization. The project implementation 
unit will be appropriately staffed. Nongovernment organizations 
will be selected and engaged to help implement land acquisition, 
the  resettlement  plan,  and  the  HIV/AIDS  and  anti-trafficking 
program.  The  consultants  will  help  procure  land  and  monitor 
project  implementation.  ADB  will  rigorously  monitor  project 
implementation  and  technical  auditing  throughout  the  project 
period  through  intensive  interactions  with  the  Government, 
MPPW,  and  other  funding  agencies.  Negative  environmental 
impacts will be mitigated through the detailed mitigation measures 
set out in the summary environmental impact assessment, which 
will be monitored by the consultants. The Government reassures 
the Project’s priority I status starting in FY2007/08 in terms of 
budget  allocation,  particularly  the  cost  of  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement. 
The Project has been prepared in full consultation with all local 
communities, which are expected to pass information to all parties 
in terms of the Project’s potential benefits to local poor people. A 
security assessment was carried out during project preparation. 
Local  communities,  including  participants  believed  to  be 
insurgents  or  related  to  insurgents,  expressed  support  for  the 
Project.  Lessons  learned  by  major  funding  agencies  active  in 
Nepal,  including  ADB,  have  been  incorporated  in  the  project 
design. In the past, pro-poor projects had a much better chance of 
being less disturbed. Security risk mitigation measures include 
(i) overprogramming  candidate  roads,  (ii)  encouraging 
employment of local contractors, (iii) incorporating an adequate 
construction  period  in  civil  works  contracts,  and  (iv)  providing 
flexible work program. Maximum use of local unskilled labor will 
be encouraged by adopting labor-intensive construction methods 
as much as practicable. All these measures are expected to help 
project implementation.  
The recent political development and newly declared cease-fire by 
the  Government  and  insurgents  provide  reasonable  hope  for 
cautious optimism for safe and effective project implementation. 
The  Government  confirmed  the  Project’s  priority  and  its 
commitment  to  continue  project  implementation,  including  all

v
agreed  assurances  in  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President  and  financing  agreement.  However,  a  cautious 
approach  will  be  adopted  and  a  security  assessment  will  be 
carried out in the process of contract award and approval of non-
sample  roads.  This  will  prioritize  sections  that  are  considered 
capable of being implemented safely and effectively and help in 
awarding contracts accordingly.  
   
Technical Assistance  In conjunction with the Project, a TA is proposed to enhance the 
capacity  building  of  (i)  DOR  in  carrying  out  road  feasibility 
studies—particularly in terms of economic analysis and social and 
safeguard  aspects;  and  (ii)  local  construction  and  consulting 
services  industries  in  road  construction  and  contract 
management. The estimated total cost of the TA is $351,000, of 
which ADB will finance $300,000 on a grant basis from ADB’s TA 
funding  program.  The  TA  consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by the 
Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
grant, and (ii) the proposed administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a loan to 
be  provided  by  the  Organization  of  Petroleum  Exporting  Countries  (OPEC)  Fund  for 
International  Development  (OPEC  Fund),  both  to  the  Kingdom  of  Nepal  for  the  Road 
Connectivity Sector I Project. The report also describes a proposed technical assistance (TA) 
grant for capacity building in road feasibility study and construction and contract management, 
and if the ADB’s Board of Directors approves the proposed grant, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Nepal's gross domestic product (GDP) growth slipped to 2% in FY2005 after recovering 
moderately to about 3% in FY2003 and FY2004, from the downturn in FY2002. Nepal is a 
landlocked country with a population of approximately 25.4 million people. It ranked 136 out of 
177 countries on the human development index in 2005, one of the lowest in the South Asian 
region.  It  faces  difficult  challenges  in  reducing  poverty  and  achieving  the  Millennium 
Development Goals. While the national poverty incidence is 30.8%, it is about 37.4–42.9% in 
northern hilly areas.  
3.  The transportation system in Nepal depends heavily on the road network which carries 
about 90% of all passengers and freight within the country. Nepal’s national road network has a 
total of 16,834 kilometers (km) of roads, comprising national highways, feeder roads, urban 
roads, district roads, and village roads. In 2002, the national highways and feeder roads, which 
form the country’s strategic road network (SRN), reached about 4,861 km. There are 51 feeder 
roads totaling 1,852 km in length which provide major connections from highways to district 
headquarters. About two thirds of feeder roads remain unpaved and much remains impassable 
during the wet season.  
4.  Road transport is the dominant transport mode in Nepal but road density is low at 
11.40 km of road per 100 square kilometers (km2) and 0.71 km per 1,000 population—less than 
that in neighboring countries. It is even lower in the northern part of the country at 5.22 km per 
100 km2 and 0.61 km per 1,000 persons. In Nepal, 15 out of 75 district headquarters are not 
connected by road and almost 53% of district headquarters are not connected by all-weather 
roads; the majority of these are in the northern hilly area. This is mainly due to the country’s 
complex topography and insufficient resources, which result in lack of road access for about 
4 million inhabitants and contribute to rural poverty throughout the country.  
5.  The number of road accidents increased by 42% from 2002 to 2003, registering 5,430. 
This rise was due to increased vehicle density together with lack of road safety measures, poor 
discipline, and enforcement and poor roadworthiness of vehicles. Although available statistics 
show that the road fatality rate has declined significantly in the last few years to 27 deaths per 
10,000 vehicles, it remains one of the highest in the region.

6.  The present road accident system is clearly inadequate in terms of data records to 
analyze  the  causes  of  accidents,.  The  data  records  can  be  utilized  to  identify  accident 
“blackspots”, detect major causes, and develop countermeasures. The Traffic Engineering and 
Safety Unit (Road Unit) was established in 1994 in the Department of Roads (DOR). It produced 
guidelines for road safety including a traffic sign manual, road safety notes, and a highway 
code;  and  conducted  training  for  traffic  police.  The  Project  will  strengthen  the  accident 
database’s software system and perform capacity training.  
7.  The bus and freight transport industry is heavily regulated. The majority of operators of 
road passenger and freight services are privately owned. Over 90% of passenger and freight 
traffic is carried by buses and trucks. Route permits must be issued for the majority of sealed 
roads. Route fares are set by considering terrain and road pavement type and condition.  
8.  During Nepal’s 10th plan, five-year period, (Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, 2002–
2007)2,  the  Government’s  total  planned  investment  in  the  road  sector  is  $485  million—a 
significant increase over the amount allocated in the previous plan period. The investment 
budget is about $73.1 million for FY2006, about 9.8% higher than that of FY2005.  
9.  The National Planning Commission sets overall development objectives and coordinates 
the  investment  programs  of  external  agencies  and  government  agencies.  The  Ministry  of 
Physical Planning and Works (MPPW) has prime responsibility for (i) planning and formulating 
road policies; and (ii) managing all land transport facilities, including roads and bridges. Within 
MPPW, DOR is responsible for network planning, design, construction, and maintenance of the 
SRN; municipalities are responsible for urban roads. The Ministry of Local Development (MLD) 
is  responsible  for  district  and  village  roads.  MLD’s  Department  of  Local  Infrastructure 
Development and Agricultural Roads (DOLIDAR) is responsible for coordinating and facilitating 
rural  infrastructure  development  throughout  the  country.  DOR’s  Project  Directorate  (ADB), 
administers ADB-financed road projects. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) provides funds for 
maintenance of the SRN through Roads Board Nepal (RBN) and DOR. Since its establishment 
on 30 December 2002, RBN approves DOR’s annual road maintenance plan and controls the 
part of DOR’s budget funded by RBN. DOR remains the planning and implementation agency 
for maintenance funded by other sources—such as direct allocation by MOF and projects 
funded by ADB and the World Bank. 
10.  RBN’s funding sources are mainly fuel levies (48.7%), vehicle registration fees (33.5%), 
and tolls (17.8%). These funds are used to maintain all roads. For FY2005/06, the total fund 
resources were NRs400 million ($5.6 million) which were allocated to SRN roads, urban roads, 
and district roads. The Government provides an additional NRs290 million ($4.1 million) to DOR 
for SRN maintenance. The Government plans to provide adequate funding each year to RBN 
and eventually budget all road maintenance funds through RBN. The Government’s budget 
support for road maintenance will continue until RBN revenue collection can fully meet the road 
maintenance fund requirement.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
  1.  Key Challenges 
    a.  SRN Extension and Maintenance Budget  
11.  Nepal’s 10th FYP recognized the need to improve rural transport connectivity to major 
towns and cities—in order to improve access and reduce transport costs to stimulate economic 
development,  particularly  in  agriculture.  Its  objectives  include  strengthening  political  and 
administrative  linkages,  poverty  reduction,  and  minimizing  the  total transportation  cost  and 
adverse environmental impact. Major strategies adopted in the 10th FYP in the road sector 
include (i) increasing private sector participation in road construction and maintenance, and 
(ii) enhancing the institutional capacities of DOR and the private sector to ensure cost-effective 
sustainability of the road network. 
12.  The 20-year Road Master Plan for SRN (RMP) (2002–2022) sets out strategies to 
extend the SRN by 4,040 km to improve north–south connectivity to district headquarters and 
centers of trade, industry, and tourism. Connection of 12 out of 15 district headquarters, which 
are  not  yet  connected  by  road  to  national  highways,  is  proposed  during  the  10th FYP; 
connection of the remaining three is planned during the 11th FYP. The Government’s 10-year 
road sector Midterm Program (MTP) (2006–2015) is the basis for selecting candidate roads for 
the Project and other external financing agencies. The MTP plans to provide new connections to 
three district headquarters and improve roads to all-weather condition in 17 districts. During the 
same period, the SRN is to be extended by 200 km per year, and will be maintained to the 
required condition. The annual estimated expenditure for extension and maintenance of the 
SRN is about NRs5,700 million ($81 million). The RMP required substantial funding agency 
support for the budget in the initial RMP period for rehabilitation and reconstruction. However, 
such support is expected to decline significantly near the end of the planning period.  
13.  Until 1990, Nepal's transportation focus was to develop basic transport infrastructure, 
constructing 8,328 km of roads by 1991. By the early 1990s, neglect of road maintenance 
began to show and 52% of major roads were in poor condition in 1992. Growing understanding 
of the consequence of poor maintenance and the Government’s focus on maintenance has led 
to massive rehabilitation and resealing of road networks, mostly through externally assisted 
projects. The Government’s efforts to strengthen road maintenance include (i) preparing road 
plans, (ii) establishing RBN, and (iii) increasing budget allocation for road maintenance. The 
RMP includes a long-term plan for road maintenance. It is estimated that about NRs1 billion 
($14  million)  will  be  required  each  year  for  SRN  road  maintenance.  In  contrast  to  road 
rehabilitation  and  reconstruction,  where  the  Government  is  largely  dependent  on  external 
assistance, it currently provides budgetary funding for routine, recurrent, and most periodic 
maintenance. The Government will provide full funding for periodic maintenance of at least 
500 km each year from 2006 to 2012. This will ensure proper maintenance of all maintainable 
SRN roads and clear up 800 km of deferred maintenance.    
b.  Institutional Strengthening 
14.  Two  significant  developments  have  occurred  through  the  Government’s  post-2000 
initiatives on institutional strengthening in public infrastructure construction and management: 
(i) the preparation of the public works directives (PWD) and, (ii) the establishment of RBN. The 
objective of the PWD is to provide a set of understandable, effective, efficient, and practical 
directives—a single source of procedures and reference documents for implementing public

4   
construction works (such as roads, irrigation, and civil aviation). The PWD has been in force 
since 2002 and is the first manual of uniform procedures for public construction works and use 
of consulting services in Nepal. The PWD combine Nepal’s financial administration rules and 
other rules and regulations on technical, social, and environmental matters. 
15.  The Roads Board Act, 2002, establishes RBN as an autonomous body to (i) manage the 
collection and expenditure of revenue for repair and maintenance of all road networks (routine, 
recurrent, periodic, rehabilitation, and emergency maintenance); and (ii) charge vehicles using 
the roads. RBN formulates an integrated annual maintenance plan each year and allocates 
budget for road maintenance works. 
16.   The importance of capacity building in the road sector has been widely recognized. 
International  funding  agencies  supported  capacity  building  in  DOR,  DOLIDAR,  and  RBN 
through several interventions. DOR prepared training management guidelines based on an 
analysis of capacity building needs. ADB provided capacity-building assistance to (i) DOR in 
preparing the PWD; and (ii) RBN in strengthening the road tariff methodology. The National 
Vigilance Centre (NVC) is one of the country’s active anticorruption agencies, specializing in 
auditing project performance in terms of procurement, contract management, and construction 
quality. ADB has supported capacity building of NVC’s technical audit to ensure transparency 
and good governance in infrastructure construction. The Swiss Agency for Development and 
Cooperation has focused on capacity building in maintenance activities at the operational level 
of DOR division staff by introducing a planned maintenance approach since 1993 through the 
Strengthening  Maintenance  Divisions  Program.  This  program  trained  staff  in  all  25  DOR 
divisions under “Yearly Plans of Operation”. The United Kingdom’s Department for International 
Development has recently focused on institutional capacity in rural infrastructure development to 
support DOLIDAR and district development communities and village development committees, 
which plan and manage transport infrastructure in rural areas.  
17.  As part of the Government’s national transport policy (2002), an extensive capacity-
building and institutional-strengthening action plan is being carried out, including (i) preparation 
of a long-term institutional strategy for the SRN; (ii) comprehensive DOR corporate planning and 
performance management; (iii) DOR planning and management, using efficient information 
technology  and  management  information  systems;  (iv)  effective  monitoring  and  evaluation 
capacity; and (v) improved project financial management.  
18.  DOR has developed basic capabilities to manage road assets and resources allocated to 
the sector. However, further capacity building is necessary in the economic, environmental, and 
social aspects of road feasibility studies. These are important areas which could impede DOR’s 
project preparation efforts. DOR’s capacity also needs to be enhanced by adopting a quality 
assurance system (QAS) in construction management. In view of its present capacity and future 
capacity building programs, it is assessed that DOR will have the capacity to carry out the 
Project. 
c.  Private Sector Development and Capacity Building 
19.  Major road sector strategies adopted in the 10th FYP include (i) increasing private sector 
participation in road construction and maintenance, and (ii) enhancing the institutional capacities 
of the private sector to ensure cost-effective sustainability of the road network. The construction 
industry is important for the economy and employment in Nepal. It is estimated that it employs 
more than 140,000 personnel, ranging from unskilled workers to engineers, and has a total 
annual  turnover  of  NRs18  billion  ($257  million).  About  14,000  contractors  are  currently

5 
registered in Nepal. They are categorized into four classes according to equipment owned, 
experience, and financial status. This classification determines the qualification to participate in 
the bidding process.  
20.  Local  contractors  in  Nepal  have  improved  their  capability  in  the  last  decade  by 
purchasing more equipment. Although the Government’s Financial Administration Rules do not 
apply to externally funded projects, they state that national competitive bidding should be used 
for  contracts  up  to  NRs250  million  ($3.5  million).  Experience  from  completed  contracts 
demonstrates that a large number of local contractors can handle contracts up to that threshold. 
21.  Consulting firms are key players in road construction and maintenance—in terms of 
planning, design, and supervision of road works. About a total of 240 consulting firms are 
registered with the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Supplies; around 45 firms are actively 
engaged in projects funded by the Government and international funding agencies, although the 
sizes of the local firms are relatively small.  
22.  The  Federation  of  Contractors’  Association  Nepal  and  the  Society  of  Consulting 
Architectural and Engineering Firms were established to advocate activities for the development 
of the construction and consulting services industry. Their main objectives include the following: 
(i) develop professional capabilities, (ii) eliminate unhealthy and unfair competition, (iii) advise 
members on technical and legal matters, (iv) suggest government formulation and amendment 
of all policies related to the construction industry, and (v) provide technical training opportunities 
to members.  
23.  Although local contractors and the consulting services industry have improved their 
technical capacity over the years—mostly through externally funded projects—the need for 
training has been identified in the International Federation of Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) 
contract management and QAS (Appendix 2 and Supplementary Appendix A). 
  2.  External Assistance 
24.  Development of Nepal’s road network is heavily reliant on external funding. Since 1976, 
ADB has provided the Government with seven transport projects totaling $219.4 million and TAs 
totaling over $3.5 million to construct or upgrade about 1,800 km of highways and feeder roads. 
These projects included (i) a large portion of road upgrading and periodic maintenance of the 
East–West Highway; and (ii) improvement of hilly roads, accounting for about 25% of Nepal’s 
road development expenditure. Major bilateral funding agencies in Nepal’s road sector include 
Germany, India, Japan, People’s Republic of China, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and United 
States.  Multilateral  funding  agencies  include  the  World  Bank  and  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme (Appendix 3). 
  3.  Lessons Learned 
25.  The road sector presents progressing experience in terms of project implementation 
performance.  Over  the  years,  MPPW  has  demonstrated  improved  capacity  to  implement 
projects.  However,  it  needs  to  strengthen  capacity  building  in  road  feasibility  studies  and 
contract management.  
26.  Efforts are being made by ADB and the Government to optimize project implementation 
in conflict situations. Experience shows that problems caused by conflict situations for most 
projects  tend  to  be  time-  and  site-specific  but  most  were  able  to  continue  without  major

6   
constraints. Although many projects experienced implementation difficulties (such as strikes) to 
some extent, contract awards and disbursements in 2005 showed improvement over year 2004. 
27.  A conservative implementation schedule is provided with adequate contingency. Active 
consultations and public participations were carried out during project preparation—particularly 
with respect to land acquisition and prevention of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking—to increase 
public awareness and address community road-related needs. This will facilitate public support 
for the Project and reduce disruptions during implementation. The sector modality provides 
flexibility in selecting subprojects in accordance with local conflict levels. Experience in similar 
projects has shown that maximum use of national competitive bidding provided the possibility of 
better coordination with local parties and less interference from insurgents, especially when 
local unskilled labor from local villages carried out some of the work. Successful implementation 
of completed works suggests that local contractors are capable of handling most types of 
roadworks under the Project. The project design considered lessons learned from previous 
projects. 
  4.  Asian Development Bank Sector Strategy 
28.  Nepal’s country strategy and program (2005–2009)3 sets out the strategy for promoting 
broad-based and inclusive social and economic development to achieve a steady decline in 
poverty.  A  key  element  is  the  development  of  the  road  network,  which  will  assist  the 
Government in (i) promoting balanced regional development; (ii) improving the poor’s access to 
basic services, opportunities for economic advancement, and participation in the development 
process; and (iii) addressing the needs of disadvantaged, women, ethnic groups, and lower 
castes. 
29.  In the transport sector, the key to mainstreaming excluded regions and social groups in 
the  economy  is  to  foster  connectivity  between  all  parts  of  the  country  and  facilitate  trade 
between  Nepal  and  its  neighbors.  ADB  supports  the  Government  in  (i)  improving  rural 
accessibility, (ii) reducing isolation within the country, and (iii) promoting subregional connectivity 
with  neighboring  countries.  The  Government  is  committed  to  improving  overall  sector 
performance and recognizes the need for a combination of network improvements, institutional 
reform,  and  improved  asset  management.  This  approach  is  supported  by  other  external 
agencies.  
30.  A programmatic approach has been adopted in identifying, screening, and prioritizing 
candidate roads (Appendix 4 and Supplementary Appendix B). Selection of candidate roads for 
the project financing may be further reviewed during the project implementation period. The 10th 
5-year MTP is based on the Government’s 20-year RMP by adopting multi-criteria analysis in 
considering district headquarters’ connectivity, economic worth and potential, population and 
road density, extent of land acquisition and resettlement, poverty, environment, construction 
cost, and security concerns. The MTP consists of (i) a 10-year road investment priority plan 
(2006–2015) in the feeder road network to improve connectivity between rural roads and major 
towns and district headquarters; (ii) recommendations to strengthen the Government’s capacity 
to manage and operate the road network safely and efficiently; and (iii) capacity training to 
strengthen the capabilities of DOR, local contractors, and consulting services to improve and 
maintain road construction and management.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
32.  The Project will (i) support sustained and broad-based economic growth and inclusive 
social development; and (ii) help reduce the poverty of isolated people, mostly in hilly areas. An 
expanded and rehabilitated feeder road system in remote areas will improve access to markets, 
employment opportunities, and health and education service centers in major towns and district 
headquarters. The capacity of DOR and local construction and consulting services industries will 
be enhanced.  
B.  Outputs 
33.  A total of 25 roads and bridge measuring about 1,383 km are included in the MTP; 10 
roads and 1 bridge totaling about 490 km are planned for investment under the Project and the 
remainder  is  envisaged  for  other  projects.  The  Project  will  finance  the  construction  and 
upgrading  of  feeder  roads  covering  17  out  of  75  districts—located  mostly  in  western, 
midwestern, central, and eastern regions—affecting about 1.4 million people. Three district 
headquarters at Chame, Diktel, and Salleri will be connected by road to national highways for 
the first time. Existing roads will be improved to all-weather condition at Bhaktapur, Dhading, 
Dolakha, Kapilbastu, Kathmandu, Khotang, Lamjung, Manang, Myagdi, Nuwakot, Okhaldhunga, 
Panchthar, Ramechhap, Rasuwa, Sindhuli, Solukhumbu, and Taplejung.  The districts covered 
by the Project are mostly poor districts. Consulting services will be provided to assist in project 
implementation and capacity building of DOR, local contractors, and consulting firms.  
  1.  Road Connectivity Component 
34.  About 10 feeder roads will be constructed or upgraded. Three sample roads (Galchi–
Trisuli–Dhunche-Syaphrubesi,  Phidim–Taplejung,  and  Tamakoshi–Manthali–Khurkot)  totaling 
about 227 km have been selected for preliminary engineering, economic, social, resettlement, 
and environmental studies; and will serve as sample for feasibility studies of non-sample roads 
(Supplementary Appendix C). 
35.  MPPW will prepare seven non-sample roads measuring about 263 km through project 
implementation consultants. The non-sample roads will be selected in accordance with selection 
criteria adopted for sample roads and in sequence of priority in the list. All subprojects must 
have an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of more than 12%, and meet government and 
ADB policy social/resettlement and environmental requirements.  
  2.   HIV/AIDS Prevention and Anti-Trafficking Program 
36.  The Project recognizes the importance of preventing HIV/AIDS and human trafficking. 
The Project provides an opportunity to link the transport sector with already existing HIV/AIDS 
and  anti-trafficking  programs  in  support  of  government  strategies,  and  increase  access  to 
HIV/AIDS  services  and  care.  The  anti-trafficking  program  will  help  mitigate  the  spread  of

8   
HIV/AIDS, so it is included in the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program to be financed by the 
grant. The Project will (i) carry out designed activities to reduce the vulnerability of groups at risk 
of HIV/AIDS and trafficking, and (ii) increase access to HIV prevention services. Beneficiaries 
will include road construction workers, transport drivers, female sex workers, migrants, and 
populations living along the road corridors. DOR officials and local government employees will 
be  trained.  This  component  has  been  formulated  on  division  of  labor  with  other  funding 
agencies and existing government programs to avoid duplication, and will be financed from the 
Asian Development Fund IX (ADF IX) grant. Background, terms of reference (TORs), and cost 
estimates are in Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix D. The HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 6.   
C.  Special Features 
37.  This is the first ADB sector road project in Nepal and a programmatic approach is used 
to prepare a 10-year road sector midterm program. This makes it possible to select road 
connectivity subprojects under a well-prepared and balanced context with a clear picture of the 
institutional  capacity,  road  investment  plan,  funding  constraints,  subproject  priority,  and 
maintenance capability in the country’s road sector.  
38.  The Project proposes a modest scale of pavement rehabilitation and resurfacing and 
other supporting works, which present a much more acceptable design in terms of economic 
efficiency and resettlement and environmental impact. 
39.  ADB has assisted Nepal in improving road safety by strengthening policy requirements, 
training, and equipment applications. The road safety program under the Project will assist in 
road safety improvement. Safety auditing will be carried out (i) during and immediately after 
completion of the detailed design, and (ii) before tendering. Improvements will be carried out on 
project roads, including road signs, and training counterpart staff. The road accident database 
will be strengthened through updated software, and staff will be trained in its application and 
maintenance.  Other  road  safety  activities  will  be  designed  and  implemented,  including 
community-oriented road safety awareness programs. The new aligned sections will meet road 
safety standards on road geometry, intersections, and side drains. On the exiting alignment, 
accident-prone  places  or  black  spots  will  be  identified  and  improved.  The  Heavy  Vehicle 
Management  Policy  to  be  adopted  by  the  Government  will  help  alleviate  the  overloading 
situation, which damages road safety and the road pavement.  
40.  Extensive consultations were held during project preparation with government agencies 
and local population on social services, minority development, environmental protection, water 
and forest resources management, and resettlement. Close consultation with external funding 
agencies active in Nepal helped formulate the HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-trafficking program 
with a clear division of labor and complementary scheme.

F.  ADF IX Grant Financing 
43.  Under the ADF IX Resolution,4 Nepal—with per capita gross national income of $230—
was classified as one of the poorest and most debt-stressed countries, and eligible for ADF 
grant financing for up to 50% of the total assistance program under category B of the ADF IX 
Grants Allocation Framework5 (the Framework). The grant will finance road connectivity and the 
HIV/AIDS  prevention  and  anti-trafficking  program.  Against  the  backdrop  of  deteriorating 
development, the principal objective of the grant is to reduce the isolation of remote rural 
communities, mostly in the hilly region, by enhancing (i) the poor’s access to basic services, 
(ii) employment opportunities, and (iii) health and education service centers in major towns and 
district headquarters. The project roads cover wide areas of poor population. Nepal is also 
eligible for grant financing for HIV/AIDS and other infectious diseases under category C of the 
Framework.6  Proposed  activities  along  the  project  areas  are  fully  supported  by  relevant 
development partners, including the United States Agency for International Development and 
the United Nations Development Programme. ADB and the Government recognize HIV/AIDS as 
a crosscutting development theme which is linked to and exacerbated by the human trafficking 
issue. The anti-trafficking program will help mitigate the spread of HIV/AIDS, so it is included in 
the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program to be financed by the grant. Grant effectiveness will 
be  assessed  within  the  broader  context  of  project  performance.  The  Project’s  design  and 
monitoring frameworks for the Project and the HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-trafficking program 
have clear indicators to measure the inputs, activities, and outputs. 
G.  Implementation Arrangements 
  1.  Project Management 
44.  MPPW will be the Executing Agency and DOR will be the Implementing Agency. Both 
have extensive experience in implementing ADB-financed road projects. The Project Directorate 
(ADB),  established  in  1987,  will  be  maintained  within  DOR  and  serve  as  the  project 
implementation unit (PIU). The PIU director (the director) will have overall responsibility for all 
aspects  of  project  implementation  and  management,  including  procurement,  progress 
monitoring, financial management, reporting, land acquisition and resettlement, and HIV/AIDS 
and  anti  trafficking  prevention  programs.  The  director  will  act  as  project  coordinator  for 
government agencies concerned. DOR will maintain the full-time director for at least the first 
2 years of project implementation and promptly inform ADB of any change of director. DOR will 
ensure  that  the  person  appointed  will  (i)  be  a  senior  officer  with  adequate  technical  and 
administration experience and qualifications; and (ii) be assisted by appropriate and adequate 
technical, financial, and administrative staff. One project office in Kathmandu and at least three 
field project offices will be set up to be responsible for day-to-day implementation and report to 
the director (Supplementary Appendix E). 
45.  The HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-trafficking component will be implemented by local 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) under the overall responsibility of the PIU. DOR will 
ensure that adequate counterpart facilities and staff assist in the implementation, and essential 
DOR officials will be trained to ensure the sustainability of DOR’s capacity after the Project.

  3.  Procurement  
47.  Procurement to be financed from the ADB grant will be carried out in accordance with

estimated  at  $100,000–$1,000,000,  and  (iii)  direct  contracting  arrangements  for  contracts

detailed  design  and  construction  supervision  of  sample  roads;  and  (ii)  feasibility  studies,

system (PPMS). Consultants will (i) supervise and monitor the implementation of resettlement

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Technical Aspect 
61.  The Project will (i) improve road geometric design, surface condition, drainage system, 
pavement strength, and bridges; (ii) widen the carriageway; and (iii) provide road signage and 
marking. This will improve the level of service, reduce vehicle operating costs (VOCs), shorten 
travel time, and improve riding comfort. The risk of road accidents caused by increased and 
faster travel will be mitigated by provision of proper safety features. The Project will also 
incorporate  environmental  consideration  in  the  design  and  construction,  including 
bioengineering in slope protection. 
B.  Policy and Institutional Improvements 
62.  The Project is built upon agreed policy reform, particularly in terms of road safety, 
technical  auditing,  and  the  establishment  and  operation  of  RBN.  Further  capacity  building 
proposed under the Project will help DOR and local construction and consulting industries to 
develop the necessary capacity to prepare feasibility studies, construction management, and 
quality assurance. The Project will also assist DOR in accumulating capacity in mainstreaming 
HIV/AIDS  prevention  and  anti-trafficking  into  road  sector  development.  Proposed  technical 
auditing will enhance the Government’s capacity and experience in dealing with irregularities in 
road sector development. 
C.  Economic Analysis 
63.  Upgraded sample roads will allow improved traffic flow, higher vehicle speeds, and 
shorter travel times. This will lead to a reduction in VOCs and time costs, which will stimulate 
economic growth and increase traffic along sample roads.  
64.  An economic assessment (Appendix 12 and Supplementary Appendix H) was conducted 
for the three individual sample roads and for the sample roads as a whole in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.8 The economic analysis considers the 
estimated costs and benefits over the construction period and 20 years of operation. The costs 
comprise investment costs and incremental operating costs. The estimated benefits are in terms 
of savings in VOCs and passenger time costs. The estimated EIRR of the overall sample roads 
is 18.0%; the EIRRs of the individual sample roads ranges from 12.7% to 23.4%.  
65.  Sensitivity analysis was carried out for five scenarios to test the economic viability of the 
Project: (i) capital costs increased by 20%, (ii) benefits decreased by 20%, (iii) exclusion of time 
savings benefits, (iv) exclusion of generated traffic benefits, and (v) capital costs increased by 
20% and benefits decreased by 20%. Under the worst scenario, the EIRR for the sample roads 
as a whole was 13.1%, above the opportunity cost of capital of 12%, indicating the economic

66.  Distribution analysis was undertaken to (i) assess the extent that the direct economic 
benefits quantified in the economic analysis would accrue to poor people, and (ii) estimate the

benefits among various categories of road users. A user survey was conducted to establish the 
proportion of the poor among passenger users, freight users, and vehicle owners/operators. 
Estimates of the poor in each of the sample road areas using passenger facilities and freight 
services varied from 42.5% to 61.4%. The estimated poverty impact ratio was 0.44, indicating 
that the total net economic benefits reaching the poor is almost 50% of the total net economic 
benefits of the sample roads.  
D.  Social Impacts 
  1.  Poverty Reduction and Socioeconomic Impacts 
67.  The districts covered by the Project are the poorest in the country. According to a survey 
in 2003–2004, the project roads are located in regions where poverty incidence is high (from 
37.4% to 42.9%) compared with the national average (30.8%). Most of these districts are also 
considered food insecure districts. As transportation has been difficult, it has been hard to 
supply food in time of need or at low cost, and people have been unable to sell agricultural 
products to neighboring markets. 
68.  The social survey indicates that better road connectivity will help farmers sell agricultural 
products to neighboring markets so that they can grow larger marketable surpluses. It will 
provide more agricultural employment, particularly benefiting the poor. The Project will also 
create employment opportunities for skilled and unskilled labor during implementation. Unskilled 
labor will be employed directly in road construction and indirectly in providing materials and 
services for contractors. The Project will enable reliable access to social services, particularly 
health care services, education facilities, and supply of drinking water. The direct (access to 
services and markets) and indirect benefits (employment) of the Project will help reduce poverty 
and improve quality of life. The Project will have limited negative social impact (Appendix 13). 
  2.  Indigenous Peoples 
69.  More than 45% of the population in the 17 districts come from ethnic groups, including 
Chepang,  Gurung,  Jirel,  Limbus,  Kala-Rai,  Kumals,  Magar,  Majhis,  Newar,  Rais,  Sherpa, 
Sunuwar, Tamang,  and, Thami.  Due to language and cultural criteria used in defining ethnic 
groups in Nepal, not all ethnic groups are socio or economically marginal. Ethnic groups in the 
project areas are all integrated into the social, cultural, and economic network of mainstream 
society. A detailed social survey conducted in the three sample road sections reveals that the 
ethnic groups present are Danuwar and Majhi, and there will be no differential impact on these 
groups from the dominant local population likely to be adversely affected by the Project. All the 
population in the areas will benefit equally from the socioeconomic opportunities created by the 
Project.  Improved  roads  will  increase  ethnic  groups’  access  to  socioeconomic  services. 
Therefore, it is not necessary to prepare an indigenous people’s development plan. Special 
mitigation measures have been included in the resettlement plans (RPs) to provide additional 
assistance to such households in the event of being adversely affected. In addition, if any 
impact is identified on indigenous people during preparation of non-sample subprojects, an 
indigenous people’s development plan will be prepared in accordance with ADB’s Policy on

Indigenous  Peoples9  in  line  with  the  indigenous  people’s  development  framework 
(Supplementary Appendix I).  
  3.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Aspects 
70.  The Project was developed with a view to avoid or minimize the need for land acquisition 
and involuntary resettlement. Road construction will largely follow the existing alignment. The 
roads pass mostly through rural areas and markets where settlements along the road are thinly 
populated rural dwellings. 
71.  Based on the preliminary technical design, a full census was conducted for the three 
sample roads for all affected persons (APs), land, and structures, assets within the corridor of 
impact of 8 meters (m), with 4 m on both sides of the existing centerline. The carriageway width 
is about 4.5 m and additional land will be required where government land is not available for 
widening and realignment. An estimated 212 households and 1,055 persons will be affected by 
the three sample roads. A total of 163 structures will be affected and seven households may 
lose agricultural land. Other impacts will include loss of community structures and incomes, and 
livelihoods of tenants and employees. Three RPs for three sample roads have been prepared to 
mitigate various impacts and the summary RP for the three sample roads combined is in 
Supplementary Appendix J. 
72.  The entitlement matrix provides for compensation and resettlement assistance to all APs 
and small businesses, including those without formal title in the project corridor of impact. In 
addition, provision has been made for additional assistance to match the replacement costs of 
lost assets, transaction costs, and other cash grants and resettlement assistance. Households 
headed by females and other vulnerable households will be eligible for further assistance. The 
total estimated cost of resettlement and rehabilitation for the Project is about $0.28 million.  
73.  MPPW has translated and disclosed the summary RP to APs and local communities in 
local languages along the sample roads. In addition, after completion of detailed designs, the 
RPs will be updated on the basis of final alignment and approved by ADB prior to the award of 
civil  works  contracts.  The  requirements  of ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement10  for 
preparing the sector project required a resettlement framework (RF) for the remaining non-
sample subprojects (Supplementary Appendix K). MPPW/DOR will prepare an RP for each non-
sample road based on detailed design in accordance with ADB’s policy and the RF. ADB will 
approve these prior to commencement of civil works. 
  4.  Gender 
74.  The  Project  will  benefit  both  men  and  women  by  providing  (i)  direct  employment 
opportunities  in  construction  activities,  (ii)  easier  access  to  markets,  (iii)  better  delivery  of 
services,  and  (iv)  improved  access  to  health  care  facilities  and  education.  Focus  group 
discussions with women and communities revealed that the majority of respondents supported 
the construction of the project roads. The civil work contracts will include legally mandated 
provisions for health; sanitation; and appropriate working conditions (including accommodation, 
where appropriate, for construction workers at campsites during the construction period). The 
Project will ensure that (i) civil works contractors comply with all applicable labor laws, including 
elimination of gender-differentiated wages; and (ii) both men and women directly affected by the

  5.  HIV/AIDS and Human Trafficking 
75.  A HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-trafficking program has been prepared to (i) reduce the 
vulnerability of risk groups to HIV/AIDS and trafficking, and (ii) increase access to HIV/AIDS 
prevention services. Beneficiaries include road construction workers, transport drivers, female 
sex workers, migrants, populations living along the road corridors, and DOR project staff. The 
first phase of work will be carried out in the three sample road sections. Based on lessons 
learned, preventive activities for the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program will be identified for 
the remaining road sections.  
76.  The HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program will comprise (i) capacity strengthening of 
locally  based  NGOs  to  undertake  HIV/AIDS  and  anti-trafficking  awareness  activities; 
(ii) information,  education,  and  communication  on  HIV/AIDS  prevention  and  anti-trafficking 
through mass media and bill boards; (iii) advocacy actions on HIV/AIDS prevention and anti-
trafficking to be organized through workshops targeting local resident communities, contractors 
involved in the road construction, transportation companies; and (iv) design of a HIV/AIDS 
prevention and anti-trafficking information campaign to be implemented along the project areas 
once opened to traffic.  
E.  Environment Impact 
77.  The overall Project is classified as category A because some roads may pass through 
environmentally  sensitive  areas  such  as  a  national  park.  Other  roads  may  involve  only 
insignificant physical interventions in terms of road condition improvement; they will be category 
B subprojects which require only initial environmental examination (IEE) reports. The Project is 
subject to the Government’s Environmental Protection Rules, 1997. Environmental assessment 
reports are required to obtain government environmental clearances before commencing civil 
works of relevant sections. These will be granted by the Ministry of Environment, Science and 
Technology (MOEST) for category A subprojects and by MPPW for category B roads. MOEST 
will approve the environmental impact assessment (EIA) for category A subprojects and MPPW 
will approve IEEs for category B subprojects.   
78.  To comply with ADB’s Environment Policy,11 the environmental impacts of three sample 
roads were assessed by undertaking IEEs for Phidim–Taplejung and Tamakoshi–Manthali–
Khurkot,  and  an  EIA  for  Galchi–Trisuli–Dhunche-Syaphrubesi.  The  first  two  sample  roads 
involve  (i)  widening  the  existing  4.5  m  road  to  single-lane  standard  roads;  (ii)  improving 
drainage;  (iii)  rehabilitating  culverts;  (iv)  constructing  causeways;  and  (v)  improving  road 
alignment,  bioengineering,  landscape,  and  road  accessories.  The  EIA  for  Galchi–Trisuli–
Dhunche-Syaphrubesi was undertaken since about 30 km of the road passes through Lantang 
National Park. Except for the potential environmental impacts to Lantang National Park, the 
overall environmental impacts of the sample roads were mostly related to construction works

F.  Project Risks 
81.  ADB’s  portfolio  performance  in  Nepal  improved  in  2005,  as  reflected  in  increased 
contract  awards  and  disbursement,  in  spite  of  very  challenging  circumstances  caused  by 
escalation of the security conflict since 2000. The Project has been carefully formulated to 
manage and mitigate risks. Advance recruitment will help expedite consultant mobilization. The 
PIU will be appropriately staffed. NGOs will be selected and engaged to help implement land 
acquisition, the RP, and the HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking program. The consultant will help 
procure  land  and  monitor  project  implementation.  ADB  will  rigorously  monitor  project 
implementation  and  technical  auditing  throughout  the  project  period  through  intensive 
interactions with the Government, MPPW, and other funding agencies. Negative environmental 
impacts will be mitigated through the detailed mitigation measures set out in the SEIA, which will 
be further monitored by consultant. The Government reassures the Project’s priority I status of 
starting in FY2006/07 in terms of budget allocation, particularly the cost of land acquisition and 
resettlement. 
82.  The Project has been prepared in full consultation with all local communities which is 
expected to pass information to all parties in respect of the potential benefits of the Project to 
the local poor people. A security assessment was carried out during project preparation. Local 
communities, including participants believed to be or related to insurgents, expressed support 
for the Project. Lessons learned by major funding agencies active in Nepal, including ADB, have 
been incorporated in the project design. In the past, pro-poor projects had much better chance 
of being less disturbed by the insurgency. Risk mitigation measures include (i) overprogramming 
candidate  roads,  (ii)  encouraging  employment  of  local  contractors,  (iii)  incorporating  an 
adequate construction period in civil works contracts, and (iv) a flexible work program. Maximum 
use of local unskilled labor will be encouraged by adopting labor-intensive construction methods 
of  construction  as  much  as  practicable. All  these  measures  are  expected  to  help  project

19
implementation.  
83.  The recent political development and newly declared cease-fire by the Government and 
insurgents  provide  reasonable  hope  for  cautious  optimism  for  safe  and  effective  project 
implementation.  The  Government  confirmed  the  Project’s  priority  and  its  commitment  to 
continue  project  implementation,  including  all  agreed  assurances  in  the  report  and 
recommendation of the President and financing agreement. However, a cautious approach will 
be adopted and a security assessment will be carried out in the process of contract award and 
approval of non-sample roads. This will prioritize sections that are considered capable of being 
implemented safely and effectively and help in awarding contracts accordingly.12

SUMMARY ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Sector Profile 
1.  Nepal’s transport infrastructure mainly consists of roads and civil aviation. Roads carry 
about 90% of all passengers and freight within the country. A key part of Nepal’s road system 
is the strategic road network (SRN). The national highways consist of the East–West Highway 
and north–south highways, linking major towns and serving much of the population. The East–
West Highway stretches from Gaddachauki at the western border with India, to Kakarbhitta at 
the  eastern  border  with  India,  runs  the  length  of  the  country  across  the  Terai,  and  is 
connected through north–south links to Kathmandu. The Tribhuvan highway is also vital, 
connecting Birganj at the southern border with India, the country’s most important trade 
border, to Kathmandu.  
2.  Road transport is the dominant mode for moving passenger and freight traffic in Nepal’s 
transport sector. However, road density is low at 11.40 kilometers (km) of road per 100 square 
kilometers (km2) and 0.71 km per 1,000 population—less than that in neighboring countries. 
This is mainly due to the country’s complex topography and insufficient resources, which 
result in lack of road access for about 4 million Nepalese. This problem is particularly acute in 
the north and western remote hilly areas and contributes to rural poverty. 
B.  Road Network 
3.  The national road network comprises national highways, feeder roads, urban roads, 
district roads, and village roads. The national highways and feeder roads form the SRN, which 
is the backbone of the national road network. Construction and maintenance of the SRN is the 
responsibility of the Department of Roads (DOR). District roads and village roads form the 
district road network. In 2002, the national road network had a total of 16,834 km of roads, 
comprising 4,861 km (29%) of strategic roads, 2,198 km (13%) of urban roads, and 9,775 km 
(58%) of district roads. Feeder Roads totaled 2,034 km in length. These roads form the major 
connections  from  national  highways  to  district  headquarters.  However,  15  district 
headquarters  are  not  connected  by  road.  About  two  thirds  of  the  road  network  remains 
unpaved and much remains impassable during the wet season, especially in hilly areas. 
C.  Traffic and Vehicle Fleet 
4.  An important feature of road transport within Nepal is the relatively low traffic volume. 
Outside Kathmandu Valley, the highest volumes are 2,500–3,000 vehicles per day (vpd) on 
the main route to the border with India. On key links in the Terai, volumes are 300–1,000 vpd, 
with flows of 100–200 vpd on the main hill roads. Earth roads at the extremities of the network 
may have traffic volumes of less than 25 vpd. Except around Kathmandu, where cars are 
common, traffic is still dominated by buses and trucks and, increasingly, motorcycles. The 
registered motor vehicle fleet in 2005 comprised 432,264 units. This represents an average 
annual growth rate of about 13%, with the highest growth in motorcycles.   
D.  Transport Planning and Coordination 
5.  The  National  Planning  Commission  sets  overall  development  objectives  and 
coordinates the investment programs of external agencies and government agencies. The 
Ministry of Physical Planning and Works (MPPW) has prime responsibility for planning and 
formulating policies; and managing all land transport facilities, including roads and bridges. 
The Ministry of Local Development (MLD) is responsible for district roads.

F.  Road Transport Services 
1.  Road Passenger Services 
13.  Operators of road passenger services are privately owned. The bus transport industry 
is regulated by DOTM at all levels. All bus operators must be registered as an individual or 
company.  Buses  are  checked  every  6  months  for  roadworthiness.  Tourist  buses  are 
registered separately and are limited to carrying tourists only.  
14.  For all-weather roads, DOTM designates the bus routes and issues route permits. 
There are no conditions on these route permits. Maximum fares for a particular route are set 
by DOTM on a route basis, and take account of road pavement type and existing peak bus 
loadings. Changes in bus fares are not immediately responsive to changes in operating 
conditions. Routes and fares are agreed between bus operators and village development 
committees where DOTM has not specified a route. Proposals for new services come from 
operators or village development committees.  
2.  Road Freight Services 
15.  Commercial vehicles must be licensed by DOTM to operate. There are two types of 
route permits for freight traffic: (i) for a specific route, and (ii) countrywide. All route permits 
must be renewed every 4 months. DOTM also approves maximum freight rates. 
16.  The  road  freight  transport  industry,  which  carries  over  90%  of  freight  traffic,  is 
dominated by private operators who are mostly owner-drivers. Most of these operators are 
members of transport associations, although a growing number of independent operators 
compete for loads and keep the market competitive. 
17.  Freight rates reflect the condition of the road. Rates on unpaved sections in hilly or 
mountainous terrain are NRs15–NRs25 per ton-km, compared with around NRs3–NRs10 per 
ton-km on paved sections in flat terrain. This general link between road condition and freight 
rates is seen in all areas.

SUMMARY HIV/AIDS PREVENTION AND ANTI-TRAFFICKING PROGRAM 
A.   HIV/AIDS Issues 
1.  Risk behavior is widespread among the mobile population, commercial sex workers, 
injecting drug users, and young people. Recent studies on highway routes highlight that these 
groups have a higher risk of being exposed to HIV/AIDS. It is estimated that there were 62,000 
people living with HIV/AIDS in Nepal in 2003 and 871 reported AIDS cases by the end of 
March 2005. The current estimated HIV infection rate is 0.5% in the economically productive 
age group of 20–49, with higher prevalence reported among migrants from remote rural areas of 
Nepal. The HIV epidemic has rapidly changed in the last 3 years and recent data show a very 
low level of HIV awareness and risk perception, especially among women. Most risk areas 
include city centers, transport junctions, corridors along highways, and areas where people 
regularly migrate for work. HIV infection has been noted in all regions of the country, although it 
is concentrated in urbanized areas and districts with high labor migration. Areas supplying more 
migrants such as the midwest and far-west regions are more vulnerable.  
B.  Trafficking in Women and Children Issues 
2.  Although progress has been made in reducing human trafficking in recent years, Nepal 
continues to be a source country for children and women trafficked overseas. They are often 
subject to abuse and are vulnerable to HIV/AIDS. Reports indicate that internal trafficking is on 
the rise because of the insurgency, as rural women and children leave to seek employment and 
security in urban centers. 
3.  Accurate data on trafficking is difficult to obtain because of its clandestine nature, and 
reported statistics vary considerably. However, 2001 census data highlights that the proportion 
of male and female absent from the household without a known reason is higher for women 
than for men, indicating their possibility of being trafficked. The Government has identified 26 
high-priority districts as source areas for trafficking and established anti-trafficking vigilance 
committees. High-risk areas for trafficking include cities, markets, highway bus junctions or 
areas to or from where migration takes place, areas with low literacy. Girls and women aged 11–
25 and boys aged 6–12 are most vulnerable to trafficking.   
C.  External Assistance to HIV/AIDS and Anti-Trafficking   
4.  In  Nepal,  there  are  more  than  50  domestic  and  international  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) working in HIV/AIDS prevention, and 57 NGOs working in anti-trafficking 
activities, in addition to United Nations agencies and government efforts. The National Center 
for  AIDS  and  Sexually  Transmitted  Disease  (STD)  Control,  under  the  Ministry  of  Health,

Anti-trafficking activities are coordinated by the Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare.  
5.  The largest funding agency for HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking initiatives is the United

6.  Awareness programs on anti-trafficking initiatives have reached 49 districts and there is 
a rich resource of information, education, and communications materials on anti-trafficking. Until 
now,  the  major  focus  has  been  on  awareness  raising,  advocacy,  networking,  and  social 
mobilization. Most anti-trafficking work has taken place in the Terai districts; the hill districts have 
received the least attention. All support is geared toward assisting the Government to implement 
its  national  action  plan  against  trafficking  in  children  and  women  for  sexual  and  labor 
exploitation. Campaigns are made to target potential victims and deter traffickers by advertising 
20-year punishment for trafficking. Such efforts are reported to have resulted in the interception 
and rescue of potential victims. The police have established women’s cells in 17 districts, which 
have helped control crime and improve investigation, protect women and children, and assist 
rescue efforts. 
D.  Existing Situation of HIV/AIDS and Human Trafficking in the Project Districts   
7.  Of the project areas, roads in the far-west and midwest regions have been identified as 
highly vulnerable to HIV/AIDS and human trafficking because of the high level of male out-
migration to overseas for seasonal employment. Until now, HIV/AIDS prevention activities have 
been  limited  to  awareness  of  schoolteachers,  with  limited  funds.  The  Project’s  social 
assessment, conducted along the three sample road areas, reports a very low level of HIV 
awareness and risk perception, especially among women. The districts in the central region are 
trafficking-prone districts.  
E.  The Proposed HIV/AIDS and Anti-Trafficking Program for the Project  
8.  The objective of the HIV/AIDS and Anti-Trafficking Program is to reduce the vulnerability 
of population groups who are at risk of HIV/AIDS and trafficking, and increase access to HIV 
prevention services. Beneficiaries include road construction workers, transport drivers, female 
sex workers, migrants, populations living along the road corridors, locally based government 
employees,  and  Department  of  Roads  (DOR)  project  staff.  The  program  will  include 
(i) increasing the level of awareness about prevention of HIV/AIDS and trafficking among the 
different communities, especially vulnerable and high-risk groups; and (ii) developing effective 
procedures to prevent AIDS and trafficking along the project areas. 
9.  The HIV/AIDS awareness campaign includes key activities such as (i) orientation and 
sensitization  of  project  personnel;  (ii)  HIV/AIDS  awareness  raising  for  contractors  and 
construction workers; (iii) a public awareness campaign and behavioral change of high-risk 
groups; (iv) condom promotion; and (v) networking with testing, counseling, and treatment 
services. Information will be distributed by NGOs regarding the nearest available services for 
testing, counseling, and treatment. 
10.  To address the risks and concerns of trafficking, sensitization will be created in the 
project areas including (i) sensitization and capacity building of project personnel; and (ii) public 
awareness raising. NGOs will perform the awareness raising among the public and target 
groups through the media and information, education, and communications materials.  
F.  Linkages with Existing Programs on HIV/AIDS and Anti-trafficking 
11.  The proposed activities along the project areas are fully supported by active funding 
agencies including the United States Agency for International Development and Joint United 
Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS in this field. Assistance from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will be carefully aligned with the resources of other funding agencies to complement

support of the National AIDS Strategy, and (ii) increase access to HIV/AIDS services and care. 
Therefore, the introduction of grant financing provides new opportunities for ADB to collaborate 
and harmonize HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking interventions with a wide range of stakeholders 
and beneficiaries, on a district-by-district basis and in the project districts, leading to enhanced

estimated  at  the  equivalent  of  $200,000. The  Program  will  be  administered  by ADB. The 
Government  will  provide  office  accommodation,  counterpart  staff,  and  other  miscellaneous

H.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The program will be executed over a period of 3 years. The Ministry of Physical Planning 
and Works (MPPW) will be the Executing Agency and DOR will be the Implementing Agency. 
The project implementation unit (PIU) will implement the program. An individual domestic social 
development  consultant  with  expertise  in  HIV/AIDS  prevention  and  anti-trafficking  will  be 
engaged by MPPW for 36 person-months over the project period.

15.  In the first phase, the program will be implemented in three road corridors. Based on

be identified for the remaining road sections.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Nepal: 
One of the main reasons for the persistence of poverty is the lack of access to market centers and 
government services (such as education and healthcare), and economic/employment opportunities—
caused by poor road condition or lack of roads. The physical exclusion created by such lack of access is 
also responsible for social exclusion of the poor and other residents in remote areas. In this context, the 
Project is primarily aimed at (i) improving the existing roads to improve the movement of people, goods, 
and  services;  and  (ii)  linking  various  important  trade/tourist/production  centers  and  places  so  that 
economic activities increase and people, especially in excluded and poverty-stricken places, get access to 
market and other essential services. The project is expected to (i) improve access of primary producers, 
such as farmers, to market centers where they can get higher prices for their high value perishable 
products; (ii) improve people’s mobility so that they can access employment opportunities outside the 
community; (iii) improve access to social services such as education and health; and (iv) reduce travel 
time cost. Therefore, by removing physical barriers through road networks and improving the policy and 
institutional capacity, the Project will improve the overall performance of the road sector—leading to 
reduction in poverty. The proposed roads under the Project pass through poverty-stricken areas and link 
trade, production, and marketing centers and other locations of economic activities and socioeconomic 
services. Therefore, the Project will contribute toward poverty reduction. 
B.  Poverty Analysis  Targeting Classification:  General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
The proposed project covers 17 out of Nepal’s 75 districts. The project districts are located mostly in 
midwestern hills, central hills, western Terai, and eastern hill regions. The districts covered by the Project 
are considered to be poor districts, except for some roads which are included because they lead to the 
north–south connection of trade routes and linkage to district headquarters, also contributing to poverty 
reduction.  
According to the 2004 Nepal Living Standard Survey (NLSS) II, these are the regions where poverty 
incidence is still high—ranging from 37.4% to 42.9% compared with the national average of 30.8%. Most 
of these districts are also considered food insecure districts. Transportation has been difficult because of 
the poor quality of roads and, in some cases, lack of roads. It has been difficult to supply food in time of 
need because of increased transportation costs, and people living in these regions have not been able to 
sell agricultural produce to neighboring markets.   
A  socioeconomic  survey  was  conducted  in  three  sample  roads  (covering  seven  districts)  with  466 
households selected randomly in the roads’ direct impact zone. Considering the national poverty line 
defined by NLSS (NRs7695.7 per capita income per year or $110), 49.4% of the sampled households 
were under the poverty line. NLSS also specified a poverty line for different regions. Three roads are in the 
“rural eastern hills” where a poverty line has been fixed at NRs8,069.6 ($115). Considering this regional 
poverty line, 51.3% of the sample households were found to be below the poverty line. This study shows 
slightly higher poverty incidence in the districts covered by the Project compared with NLSS II’s result 
(42.9% below poverty) for this region. This shows that within the eastern rural hills, districts covered by the 
Project are poorer than the regional average.

During project preparation, stakeholder meetings were held both at the institutional level in Kathmandu 
and with the community and related agencies in the districts and communities. Meeting and group

participation of representatives from all socioeconomic groups in the community. Small meetings and 
focused group discussions were also held exclusively with vulnerable groups comprising women, the 
disadvantaged, and indigenous people. 
The  Project  was  developed  based  on  consultation  with  possible  stakeholders  such  as  government 
agencies, the private sector, chamber of commerce, civil society, the contractor’s association, transport 
associations, communities, indigenous people and their associations, and women and their associations. 
The participation of stakeholders in the implementation of the Project has been further emphasized. The 
possibility of including the community—particularly the poor, women, and indigenous people—in the road 
construction/improvement has been incorporated. Communities were also consulted to reduce the adverse 
impacts of the Project in terms of resettlement impact.  
 
To understand the concerns of people and various stakeholders in the three sample roads, participatory 
discussions and studies (such as focus group discussions, social mapping, and key informant surveys) 
were held in seven districts. Project affected communities, local leaders, women, indigenous people, 
traders,  transport  companies,  laborers,  porters,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  civil  society 
members, and government agencies were consulted to understand (i) how they felt about the advantages 
and disadvantages of the roads; (ii) how they were going to be negatively affected; (iii) how that could be 
reduced or mitigated; and (iv) how local people, especially the poor, women, and indigenous people, could 
participate in the Project. The Project’s beneficiaries unanimously expressed the need for the Project 
primarily  because  of  its  socioeconomic  benefits.  They  also  made  suggestions  with  regard  to  local 
communities’ participation in the Project, especially in form of employment. The creation of work through 
the Project and employment will reduce the need to out-migrate for cash income.

delivery of services, improved social facilities, and improved access to better quality health care facilities 
and higher education. Focus group discussions with women and communities revealed that the majority of
